question_text: What is a filibuster? I keep hearing about it but I truly don’t understand what it means and why it’s such a big deal?
answer1: A filibuster is a parliamentary procedure where debate on a bill is extended, essentially preventing a vote from taking place. This can be done by any senator, and in the past, it was used as a way to stall civil rights legislation. Nowadays, it's often used as a tactic to delay or prevent a vote on a bill, or to force the Senate to reach a 60-vote supermajority.
answer2:
Originally, senators debated bills or confirmations. A senator can speak as long as he wants in this debate, and in the past they spoke for days to delay a bill, even reading from a phone book to pass the time. That's a filibuster. The rest of the Senate can shut him up with 60 votes to allow debate to continue (cloture). The Senate could only consider one bill at a time, so this held up the entire work of the Senate, even stopped the people of the same party from getting their bills heard. Filibusters were very politically expensive and individually exhausting, so they didn't happen much.
Over the years this has evolved. Back in the 1970s the Democrats allowed two legislative tracks, making it less politically expensive. The number of filibusters shot up after that. It eventually involved into not having to actually speak, and now any senator can stall a bill simply by saying so. Filibusters are now politically cheap, so they happen all the time, any bill or confirmation that is in any way contentious.

question_text: What's the difference between "Appeal to Authority" fallacy and "citing an authority" Whats the difference
answer1:
​
"I believe that the earth is round because I asked an Astrophysicist and they told me it was true."
This is 'citing an authority'. You are citing information from a person who is an authority on the subject of the question.
​
"I believe that the earth is flat because my elected Senator told me so."
This is an 'appeal to authority' fallacy. You are citing information from a person who is in an authoritative position, but who may not necessarily have knowledge of the subject of the question.
​
\*Apologies for the potentially political nature of the example question, I couldn't think of a better one.
answer2:
We use different standards of proof when arguing. Sometimes, like in a mathematical proof, we want something that absolutely is correct if our premises are correct.
Since we can never say "This Authority is absolutely correct about all their assertions", then trying to claim such is a logical fallacy.
However, on a more practical heuristic level where absolute certainty isn't the goal but a reasonable guess at what's probably right is, then citing an authority is a reasonable guideline if you think the methods for declaring someone an authority were justified. For instance, if a great majority of the doctors in your country are well-trained, and they think epidemiologists are the best at knowing how to handle disease outbreaks, and they think that, say, Anthony Fauci is the best viral epidemiologist out there, then it might be reasonable to accept his advice on the subject as persuasive.
